Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determination of Ni-Fe-Cr Species Dependent Transport Through Control of Temperature, Irradiation, and Grain Size
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Ni-Fe-Cr based fcc alloys (e.g., Ni-based and austenitic steel alloys) are frequently used as structural materials in a wide range of technologies, including nuclear reactors. Many aspects of Ni-Fe-Cr alloy microstructural evolution, particularly under irradiation, are controlled by point defect transport with species dependencies that are still poorly understood. In this project a novel approach to determine the species-dependent diffusion coefficients in Ni-Fe-Cr steel alloys is proposed. It is based on measurements and modeling of Radiation Induced Segregation (RIS) of nanocrystalline materials. The proposed work integrates multiple approaches to understanding point defect transport in Ni-Fe-Cr and to RIS, including grain size control, RIS characterization tools (STEM-EDS, Focused Ion Beam, TEM, and Atom Probe tomography), and multiscale ab initio based models (including cluster expansion, kinetic Monte Carlo and rate theory modeling). The work will provide a new level of insight into the magnitude and mechanisms of Ni-Fe-Cr species-dependent transport and inform future microstructural modeling.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Ni-Fe-Cr based steels are frequently used as structural materials in a wide range of technologies, including nuclear reactors. Essential aspects of the long-term reliability of these steels, particularly under irradiation, are controlled by aspects of Ni, Fe, and Cr diffusion that are still poorly understood. The PIs propose to integrate tools from materials nanotechnology and molecular-scale computer simulation to provide new levels of insight into how Ni, Fe, and Cr are transported in these steels under extreme conditions. The results will be integrated into higher levels models that aid in the prediction of steel reliability and the development of new materials. This project will train graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to work on a multi-location team and in fundamental areas of materials characterization, modeling, and their interaction. This work will also further the involvement by some of the investigators in the Women in Nuclear Science (WINS) organization and activities at the Advanced Test Reactor National Scientific User Facility (NSUF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advanced metal alloys play a central role in the nuclear industry, making up many of the components of the present day reactor, as well as providing some of the most promising materials to enable next generation reactors to operate more efficiently and safely. However, steels degrade under the radiation present near nuclear reactor cores, and an understanding of these degradation mechanisms under irradiation is critical to the safe and effective use of these materials. This work focused on a some of the most critical ways irradiation impacts metal alloys, specifically, radiation induced segregation (RIS), which is the change of composition near grain boundaries under irradiation, and radiation induced defects (RID), which is the formation of defect clusters (dislocation loops and voids) in the alloy under irradiation. Both RIS and RID can degrade metal alloy mechanical and chemical properties and need to be understood and controlled. Here we explore how RIS and RID couple to the composition and microstructure of the alloy, including grain boundaries and grain size. We focus on model Ni-Cr alloys and irradiation with protons and Ni ions. We formed an interdisciplinary team of researchers from Drexel University and University of Wisconsin – Madison to apply powerful experimental and simulation tools to this problem.

One part of our work focused on RIS in grain boundaries. Figure 1 shows how Cr concentration is depleted in different types of grain boundaries, as revealed by both electron microscopy and computer simulation. The ability to understand which grain boundaries provide improved radiation resistance with reduced Cr depletion will help researchers to develop new alloys with improved radiation tolerance.  We also observed an anomalous effect resulting from radiation-enhanced grain boundary migration coupled with grain boundary segregation was observed in the proton-irradiated materials. Micron-scale regions denuded in radiation-induced defects and also depleted in Cr were seen in all our Ni-Cr compositions. An example of such a region is shown in the electron microscopy image in Figure 2. It is hypothesized that these denuded and RIS affected regions are caused by rapid, oscillatory motion of the grain boundary throughout the region, preventing the nucleation of radiation-induced defects and maintaining the strong RIS. This result suggests that under irradiation grain boundaries can move exceptionally quickly, which make lead to instability in the grain microstructure of metal alloys over long-time and/or high-temperature nuclear applications.

The other part of our work focused on RID in alloys with varying composition and grain size. It was found that Cr content in Ni-Cr alloys changes defect nucleation behavior, especially with dislocation loop formation, resulting in a higher density of smaller loops for increased Cr composition. Increasing the irradiation temperature had the opposite effect, with higher temperatures resulting in a lower density of larger-sized loops and voids. Computational models were able to reproduce these effects and demonstrate how small changes in binding energetics of defects could lead to the observed concentration and temperature dependence. Of particular interest is that we showed that smaller grain sizes (below one micro and even below 100 nanometers) have reduced size and density of irradiation induced defects. The trends of defect density with different irradiation doses as a function of grain size are shown in Figure 3. We hypothesize that the increased volume density of grain boundaries in smaller-grained metals provides more sites for annihilation of defects and reduces the average distance of travel of a defect to an annihilation site. The results indicate that defect agglomeration is prevalent beyond one displacement per atom (dpa, a measure of amount of irradiation) irradiation dose, and that irra...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Advanced metal alloys play a central role in the nuclear industry, making up many of the components of the present day reactor, as well as providing some of the most promising materials to enable next generation reactors to operate more efficiently and safely. However, steels degrade under the radiation present near nuclear reactor cores, and an understanding of these degradation mechanisms under irradiation is critical to the safe and effective use of these materials. This work focused on a some of the most critical ways irradiation impacts metal alloys, specifically, radiation induced segregation (RIS), which is the change of composition near grain boundaries under irradiation, and radiation induced defects (RID), which is the formation of defect clusters (dislocation loops and voids) in the alloy under irradiation. Both RIS and RID can degrade metal alloy mechanical and chemical properties and need to be understood and controlled. Here we explore how RIS and RID couple to the composition and microstructure of the alloy, including grain boundaries and grain size. We focus on model Ni-Cr alloys and irradiation with protons and Ni ions. We formed an interdisciplinary team of researchers from Drexel University and University of Wisconsin – Madison to apply powerful experimental and simulation tools to this problem. One part of our work focused on RIS in grain boundaries. Figure 1 shows how Cr concentration is depleted in different types of grain boundaries, as revealed by both electron microscopy and computer simulation. The ability to understand which grain boundaries provide improved radiation resistance with reduced Cr depletion will help researchers to develop new alloys with improved radiation tolerance. We also observed an anomalous effect resulting from radiation-enhanced grain boundary migration coupled with grain boundary segregation was observed in the proton-irradiated materials. Micron-scale regions denuded in radiation-induced defects and also depleted in Cr were seen in all our Ni-Cr compositions. An example of such a region is shown in the electron microscopy image in Figure 2. It is hypothesized that these denuded and RIS affected regions are caused by rapid, oscillatory motion of the grain boundary throughout the region, preventing the nucleation of radiation-induced defects and maintaining the strong RIS. This result suggests that under irradiation grain boundaries can move exceptionally quickly, which make lead to instability in the grain microstructure of metal alloys over long-time and/or high-temperature nuclear applications. The other part of our work focused on RID in alloys with varying composition and grain size. It was found that Cr content in Ni-Cr alloys changes defect nucleation behavior, especially with dislocation loop formation, resulting in a higher density of smaller loops for increased Cr composition. Increasing the irradiation temperature had the opposite effect, with higher temperatures resulting in a lower density of larger-sized loops and voids. Computational models were able to reproduce these effects and demonstrate how small changes in binding energetics of defects could lead to the observed concentration and temperature dependence. Of particular interest is that we showed that smaller grain sizes (below one micro and even below 100 nanometers) have reduced size and density of irradiation induced defects. The trends of defect density with different irradiation doses as a function of grain size are shown in Figure 3. We hypothesize that the increased volume density of grain boundaries in smaller-grained metals provides more sites for annihilation of defects and reduces the average distance of travel of a defect to an annihilation site. The results indicate that defect agglomeration is prevalent beyond one displacement per atom (dpa, a measure of amount of irradiation) irradiation dose, and that irradiation temperature is a considerable factor as well.
